title: 110_hr3469
content:
The Act may be cited as the "America's Border Security Act of 2007" and includes provisions related to technological assets. The "America's Border Security Act of 2007" aims to increase the availability and use of Department of Defense equipment, such as unmanned aerial vehicles and surveillance equipment, to assist in preventing illegal immigration at the international land borders of the United States. A report detailing the current use of this equipment and associated risks must be submitted to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The "America's Border Security Act of 2007" aims to increase the use of Department of Defense equipment for surveillance of international land borders. The Secretary of Homeland Security will conduct a pilot program using unmanned aerial vehicles along the Canada-US border. The Act does not alter the prohibition on using the Army or Air Force as a posse comitatus. The "America's Border Security Act of 2007" authorizes appropriations for the Secretary of Homeland Security to use Department of Defense equipment for border surveillance. The Act does not change the prohibition on using the Army or Air Force as a posse comitatus. SEC. 3. INFRASTRUCTURE.

The Secretary of Homeland Security is directed to construct roads, acquire vehicle barriers, and facilities for border control. Quarterly progress reports to Congress are required, with authorized appropriations for fiscal years 2008 through 2012.

SEC. 4. PORTS OF ENTRY.

The Secretary is authorized to build new ports of entry and improve existing ones along the international land borders of the United States.

SEC. 5. SECURE COMMUNICATION. The Secretary of Homeland Security is tasked with developing a plan to enhance satellite communication for Border Patrol agents and other security agencies to ensure clear and secure communication in various operational scenarios. SEC. 6. UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLES. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to acquire and maintain at least 5 unmanned aerial vehicles and related equipment for border patrol, including sensors, spares, command and control systems, and operational support. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2008 and 2009. The Secretary of Homeland Security is mandated to develop and implement an aerial surveillance program using unmanned aerial vehicles to enhance border security with Canada and Mexico, ensuring continuous monitoring of each mile of the international borders. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to develop an aerial surveillance program using various technologies, consult with the Secretary of Defense and the FAA, and ensure safety and regulation for implementation. The aerial surveillance program developed under this subsection must use various technologies in different terrains, including near international borders, to assess the effectiveness, cost, and privacy concerns of these technologies for border security. The Secretary of Homeland Security may continue using aerial surveillance technologies for border security while assessing their effectiveness. A report must be submitted to Congress within 180 days, including program details and recommendations for improvement. Appropriations are authorized for this program. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to establish the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program for border security, including unmanned aerial vehicles, cameras, sensors, and radar coverage. Appropriations are authorized for this program. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program aims to integrate technologies for automated surveillance, including motion sensor alerts and cameras that pan and tilt automatically. Cameras do not require manual operation, have flexible views, and can be viewed at multiple communication centers. A standard process is used for collecting and reporting intrusion data, and future technology upgrades can be integrated with existing systems. The Program aims to develop performance measures to evaluate effectiveness in detecting illegal intrusions along US borders, streamline site selection processes, and expand the shared use of existing structures for surveillance technology installation. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program aims to expand the use of existing structures for installing surveillance technology and develop standards for mobile surveillance platforms to enhance border security. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to report to Congress on the Program's implementation and evaluate contractor performance. The Secretary of Homeland Security must develop standards to evaluate contractors providing goods or services for the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program. The Inspector General reviews new contracts over $5,000,000 to ensure compliance with cost requirements, performance objectives, and schedules, reporting findings to the Secretary in a timely manner. The Inspector General must report review findings to the Secretary of Homeland Security promptly. The Secretary then submits a report to the Senate and House Committees on Homeland Security, detailing the findings and any planned responses. Appropriations are authorized as needed for this subsection. SEC. 8. HIRING AND TRAINING OF BORDER AND TRANSPORTATION SECURITY PERSONNEL. During fiscal year 2008, the Secretary of Homeland Security is required to increase the number of full-time agents and support staff in the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement by 400, and in the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection by 600. The Secretary is authorized to waive any personnel limitations to fulfill these requirements. Ongoing training will be provided to ensure proficiency levels of personnel in utilizing new technologies for border protection. The Secretary of Homeland Security must prepare and submit a National Border Security Plan to Congress by January 31 each year. The plan includes a vulnerability assessment of each port of entry on the northern and southern borders, with the option to establish port security coordinators for assistance.
